awd_titl_txt: IMREL-CHRNS Partnership for Research and Education in Materials (IC-PREM) using a National Facility
awd_abstract_narration:
Fayetteville State University (FSU) is a minority-serving institution with over 70% of students classified as minorities, primarily African Americans, and with high female, military or military-affiliated student populations. This award to FSU supports research on neutron scattering of nanomaterials through the NSF Partnerships for Research and Education in Materials (PREM) program. The established partnership is defined between the Interdisciplinary Materials Research and Education Laboratory (IMREL) at FSU funded by NSF, and the Center for High Resolution Neutron Scattering (CHRNS), a national user facility co-funded by NSF and by the NIST (National Institute of Standards and Technology) Center for Neutron Research (NCNR). The IMREL houses equipment and instrumentation for materials synthesis, fabrication, processing, characterization and property measurements for nanomaterials research, and CHRNS provides state-of-the-art neutron scattering instrumentation to the general scientific community with broad applications in materials research, such as polymers, metals, ceramics, magnetic materials, porous media, fluids and gels, and biological molecules. The FSU investigators and undergraduate students are supported to visit and conduct onsite collaborative research annually with CHRNS scientists on various synthesized nanomaterials using neutron scattering at CHRNS. FSU's facilities will also be made available to CHRNS-affiliated scientists and to the CHRNS user community for complementary research at FSU as needed. This IMREL-CHRNS PREM (IC-PREM) project will enhance the materials research capacities and promote the education in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) at FSU. The national user facility CHRNS is utilized to enhance the minority education in this PREM project.

The research focus in this project is to use the neutron scattering at CHRNS to understand the structure-processing-property relationship of nanomaterials. The IMREL and CHRNS investigators have identified research directions with mutual interests for synergistic collaborations in these three thrust areas: (1) tailoring one-dimensional inorganic perovskite nanofibers for enhanced physical and chemical properties; (2) optoelectronic properties of two-dimensional hybrid perovskites; and (3) synthesis, manipulation, and characterization of nanomaterial pseudocrystals. These fundamental research projects will explore new enhanced physical and chemical properties by delicately tailored inorganic nanoscale perovskite nanofiber architectures through changing the shape, dimensionality, size, processing and chemical doping; potentially find new optoelectronic properties of two-dimensional hybrid perovskites through the study of isotope effects, cation substitution, structural defects and structural dimensionality; and achieve enhanced electrical, optical and thermal properties through surface modifications with nanocrystals. Neutron scattering by the partner, CHRNS, is a centerpiece method to characterize these crystalline and magnetic nanostructures that cannot be done by other means to guide the investigations in each of the research areas.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This Partnerships for Research and Education in Materials (PREM) project was funded to build and support the growth of a long-term partnership between the Interdisciplinary Materials Research and Education Laboratory (IMREL) at Fayetteville State University (FSU), funded by NSF, and the Center for High Resolution Neutron Scattering (CHRNS), a national user facility co-funded by NSF and the NIST (National Institute of Standards and Technology) Center for Neutron Research (NCNR).

This PREM project leveraged the partner's state-of-the-art neutron and X-ray scattering techniques to advance materials research, significantly enhancing research capacities at FSU and promoting broader participation in materials research and STEM education. Collaborative research was conducted in three major areas: tailoring inorganic perovskite structures by neutron diffraction to improve physical and chemical properties, investigating the optoelectronic properties of two-dimensional hybrid perovskites, and synthesizing, manipulating, and characterizing nanomaterial pseudo-crystals. Neutron scattering and associated X-ray scattering techniques provided by the partner institution were successfully utilized for material structural investigations to understand the relationship between structure and properties. This research yielded 18 publications, with one recognized as a top 5% highly cited paper by the Royal Chemical Society.

This project significantly enhanced STEM education at FSU. With the PREM award, the investigators developed three “Materials Science”-related programs: a BS in Chemistry with a Materials Science Concentration, which integrates materials science education for chemistry majors; a Materials Science Graduate Certificate Program that provides advanced education for students preparing for graduate school or career development; and a BS in Materials Science and Manufacturing Program, which creates new career opportunities in the manufacturing sector. Each year, 6–7 highly motivated undergraduate and high-school students were recruited for research training. Six students participated in SURF or CORE summer internship programs at NIST, supplemented by additional on-site training. In total, 12 students contributed to research publications, with some serving as first authors. This program produced 10 PREM graduates. Of these, six were admitted to Ph.D. programs at R1 research universities with full financial support, including Georgia Tech (1), North Carolina State University (1), Purdue University (1), University of Virginia (1), and Virginia Tech (2). One graduate entered a master’s program, and two began careers in industry as lab technicians. Among these graduates, 80% are women, and 70% are classified as minorities. This project also supported two early-career postdoctoral scientists, including one woman. One of these postdoctoral fellows has since started a career as an Assistant Professor.

The project fostered a strong materials research team and promoted research activities and collaborations at FSU. Ten faculty and staff members from diverse disciplines participated, including materials science, chemistry, physics, biology, computer science, and mathematics, representing all three STEM departments at FSU. The partner institution provided FSU faculty and staff professional development opportunities, including neutron schools and workshops. With PREM support, the FSU team secured eight federally funded grants for materials research and STEM education. Additionally, three tenure-track Assistant Professors received tenure and were promoted to Associate Professors during this award period. This PREM seed award empowered the PREM team to assume leadership roles in research and education initiatives at FSU.

This project also had impacts on the partner institution. Six scientists from the partner institution actively contributed to the PREM project, visiting FSU to deliver lectures and seminars to faculty and students, including five online seminars during the pandemic. Following the temporally closure of neutron facilities in 2021 due to technical issues, the partner institution secured alternative neutron resources to sustain collaborative research at Oak Ridge National Laboratory and the University of Missouri. Through this partnership, scientists at the partner institution expanded their research in materials science, particularly inorganic catalysts, phosphors, and polymers, while enhancing their roles in education. Additionally, the FSU team supported staff career development, leading to a junior team member from the partner institution securing a position as an Assistant Professor. This PREM seed award fostered a robust and enduring partnership between IMREL and CHRNS, advancing materials research and STEM education.
